I’ll just say this: if you like bourbon, unpeated scotch, sherry and spicy finishes- this one knocks it out of the park.🤘🏼 enjoy!

Very good stuff. Notes of chocolate, nuts, floral notes, vanilla, mint, raisins, spices, and toffee with a nice creaminess. Down smooth. This is actually my least favorite of the Glenmorangie extra matured line and seeing how this does well shows how good Glenmorangie is at finishing.

Sweeter than the original, but richer and more enjoyable. Not terribly complex, but the PX aging gives the sweet undertones while the oloroso sherry adds a pop of bright fruits and flavors with a slight tingle on the palette. A nice, predictable and enjoyable dram.
First try at the whisky bar. Rich and easy drinking. The palate brings raspberries, chocolate, and sugared black cherries.
gentle, complex, interesting, good heat, I like
A little too much sherry for me, and that's saying a lot. Still, nice smooth dram, would go well with dessert to balance the sweetness.
Smooth, light and easy drinking, nice little smoke on back end.  Much better than the original.
2.75 Muted sherry nose.  Slightly bitter and astringent on the palate.  Still noticeably Scotch, but with dry red wine notes especially on the finish.
I must say that I start loving this bottle more and more with each dram. Non chillfiltered , 46% ABV, your typical Sherry flavors, sweet raisins and red berries, perfect for after dinner.
At Mark’s ... lots of sherry. Surprised by how much I liked it. MaCallan-ish in the middle. 3.5/5
Very nice, smooth but flavoursome whisky
Pretty generic sherry finished highland malt, nothing wrong with it. I actually get some complexity on the finish. 90
My first single malt. I would recommend choosing Nectar d’or instead.
Highlands. Sherry, raisin, hazelnut, medium.  Burn. Oloroso sherry and bourbon barrels.

0/100

Absolutely awful. Would never buy again. Thank God it was only a taster.
Candy on the nose...somewhat spicy on the end, probably from the bourbon casks. Extremely sweet in the mouth that lingers. You get the chest feel from a bourbon but way too sweet to be.

Smells like candy and wine. Apparently that’s sherry says my friend. Some pepper in the smell too. Damn that’s sweet. Wait there’s some spice too but it’s all this sweet pepper corn flavor. Tiny bit of burnt wood on the finish and some warmth in my chest like from a bourbon too. This is nice.

Finishing off my bottle tonight. I would give this an overal 4 stars if the price was lower. I still love a nice sherry flavour profile, delicious taste of dried fruits and fairly spicy. Pairs well with a cigar!

Nose-  Smoky with light caramel and citrus.  Alcohol is noticable.

Taste-  Citrus and tobacco.  Very dry flavor profile.  A few drops of water brought out floral notes and more smoke.

Finish-  Dry short finish but very smooth.
Solid 3.5 Stars

Nose: strong alcohol. Sweet fruit. Citrus. 
Taste: Strong Alcohol overpowering. Citrus. Sweet. A bit medicinal but Smooth finish.
oilily up front, sweet cherry oak finish. somewhat hot.
Oak and honey. Plums and raisins. Strong bright cherry finish. Its miles ahead of the port finish but its not something I'd go out of my way to drink.
long time go to. light, clean, straight forward, and delightful flavor. I keep this stocked at home.
The sherry imparts way too much 'sour' for my tastes. It's overly-sweet and hot.

Tasted at a Glenmorangie vertical tasting. Had already tried the old version and rated it 3 stars. This new version is the 10 original aged in Oloroso Sherry Casks as the older one but also in PX Casks. I don’t know what kind of magic the PX did but this is clearly far superior than it was before. Now a 4 stars, and recommend that if you tried the old one and thought it was just regular, try this one and find out how better it is now.
Not my favorite from the distiller
Really sweet, but not too smooth. Nothing special
sweeter than original with less peat. sherry cask is very noticeable
Not as good as Quinta Ruben
A bit harsh in the nose and finish, but exceptionally light and honey sweet on the palette. I like this one

Got this as a sample with another bottle. First thoughts were that it is not typical of a Glenmorangie. I was surprised to get a little smoke on the nose but tasted sweet as well which was more to be expected. Complex with a nice warmth to it. I think I could really learn to appreciate this one if I had a full bottle but I also believe there are better options out there for me at this price point.
Sherry finish is a distraction, a bit off compared to other sherry finishes. Disappointing for the price

FLAVOUR:
Warm
Walnut

EXPERIENCE:

The nose has much more berry and nut notes than the Quinta which is coming from the Sherry casks. The palette is chocolate with dark berry and nut. Great winter sipping whiskey. So far this is my favorite of the Glenmorangie line up.  outstanding
Tasted at whiskey fest out of the 12’s I liked this the least but more than the 10 very flavourful but nectar and Quinta are just ridiculously good and unique
nose was chocolate old boot leather and heavy like oil.  complex flavors like peaches,  honey,  cream with a finish of sweet tobacco
Has enjoyable moments, but not digging the spice. It’s too forward.

Color reminds me a lot of apple juice. Aroma is fruity with a hint of wine and caramel in the background. Taste is a bit alcohol forward, but a bit hard to separate out individual notes until the Sherry peaks through. Finish is nicely balanced and really is the strongest part of this Scotch. A touch of water reveals some fruit and caramel, but also adds a touch of bitterness on the finish.
Really nice scotch. You can definitely taste the Sherry aging but it is balanced nicely by the spiciness of the back end. Definitely heavy berry notes along with cinnamon and Christmas spice.
I’m fond of the sherry cask finish here. It adds a lot of character.

Look: Burnt orange, a bit darker than Glenmorangie 10, Lasanta shows the influence of two more years in a barrel. Translucent, plenty of lacing and some alcohol legs. 

Nose: There’s your typical scotch pear and vanilla that hits me, but also an addition of sherry notes - dark fruits, berries, and surprisingly some smoke. Inhaling fairly deeply, you can get some spice notes as well. 

Palate: Dark fruit berries, slight vanilla, but not the pear orange that I get from the base so much. Letting the scotch settle on the tongue gives more mild, sweet flavors, and some spice I’d get from a lot of rye heavy bourbons. 

Finish: Barrel, earthy notes and sherry. I also get the bitter earthy flavor you would after eating a grape. The longer I sip, the more I get a chocolate coffee thing going. Medium finish in length, and not especially hot. 

Overall: I like Lasanta, but I’m not sure I like it as much as Glenmorangie 10.  The sherry really adds a new layer to the whiskey, but may take away some flavors.
I remember liking it but not wanting to purchase my own.
Super smooth, easy drinking. Great scotch.
Smooth with full caramel flavor.  Just a nice burn on the finish.
Great sherry influence, much better than the original

Very mild Scotch... it would be great for a beginner to work their way into the whisky world. 
The tasting notes are spot-on.
My gateway Scotch. Great introduction into this new rabbit hole. The cask finish makes it very drinkable for a newbe.
Easy sipping with sweet/nutty notes. Basically, a reasonable whiskey with a Frangelico finish.
A very nice, well rounded sipper.

nez:sucre brun et fruit secs. ça sent l'alcool.

bouche: et ça goute l'alcool aussi!! j'aime beaucoup la distillerie mais celui là me laisse perplexe. ou sont les fruits frais de Glenmorangie??? sucré, frais, canneberges séchées, harsh, feeling de jeune bourbon et texture qui laisse a désiré. trop dilué et Sharp sur l'alcool. rien ne me plaît...

finale : brûlures d'alcool et fruits secs. relativement courte.

overall : j'arrive pas a croire que c'est Glenmorangie qui a fait ça!! pas dans ma palette de goût, peu complexe et dilué. content d'avoir goûté dans un bar et de ne pas avoir acheté de bouteille!! 50% car ça passe pas l'examen!!

It may be the case that the additional two years in the Sherry cask are just too much for the 10 year original juice. I remember an episode that ralfy posted a couple years ago critiquing a sherry finished malt in which the cloak of Sherry influence completely took over any other character in the malt, and that's what happened here.

Very sweet nose of grape must, raisins, light brown sugar, balsamic. Very sweet palate of similar notes, slightly cloying. Quick finish. This is so off balance from the weighty sherry cask.

Even though the 10 year is a fairly quiet and soft whisky, I'd take its superior balance and more moderate sweetness over this one.

Odor: 
Starts similar to the 10 year. Strong sweet smell that masks the rest of the whisky. 

Taste: No smoke. Starts as whisky but moves to sherry. Not too overpowering, but the tastes occur more simultaneously, rather than merge into one. 

Finish: 
More palatable than the 10 year due to competition between the whisky and sherry flavors. Both linger.

Rum raisin on the nose, smooth raisin cake on the palate, medium spicy finish

Olfato: frutos secos, maças vermelhas (se não estou louco, rs), aroma cítrico (aroma de laranja clássico desta destilaria), assim como as típicas notas de Jerez Oloroso.

Paladar: basicamente as mesmas notas identificadas no aroma, mas com um grande reforço das notas doces provenientes dos barris que envelheceram o vinho Pedro Ximenez. O apimentado chega com mais força, mas sem agredir demais o paladar. Delicioso.

Finalização: média para longa, seguida de uma boa picância e um leve amargor no final da língua.

Impressões gerais: whisky muito bom balanceado, arredondado, e um dos melhores da linha padrão da destilaria. Recomendado para iniciantes e experts, seja puro ou mesmo com uma esfera bem grande de gelo.

I bought the Glenmorangie Taster Pack for $34.95, which includes 4 x 100 mL of Glenmorangie Original 10Y and the three primary finished versions. That breaks down to $8.74 for each, which is overpriced for the original but decent value to try the Lasanta. (In NC the 750 mL is $54.95.) The Lasanta barely beats out the Quinta Ruban, mainly on taste and finish. The nose is more subtle, you need to deeply inhale to get the same effect as a whiff from the Quinta. However, it tastes of a Christmas dessert with nuts and dried fruits, and not as sticky on the finish. I really enjoyed this taster pack, but damn are Glenmorangie options expensive. If you buy a bottle, I recommend everything but the Nectar.

Nose
• The sweetness is immediately apparent with notes of sherry, snickerdoodle, floral, and a little blueberry. The floral notes continue as more lovely smells arise. Slight tannic notes are present, but are less apparent than the Original 10 year. Some honey notes waft in and continue the floral character.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Taste
• Momentarily very sweet, but quickly develops a wonderful complexity, blending notes of flowers, spices, honey, malt, and oak. The spices are more floral and herbacious than peppery. After a few minutes of sipping and savoring, the signature slightly astringent/citric Glenmorangie notes are more apparent, but work well with the spirit instead of overwhelming it.
• The finish of the whiskey is somewhat dry. The sweetness and spices taper off slowly and leave a slight cooling sensation in your mouth. It works with the remaining sweetness to remind you of cake icing.

Overall, I think the sherry finish offers a great window into to the sherried whiskey style and that this offering outclasses the Original 10 Year Glenmorangie by a significant margin. The whiskey is complex, approachable, and quite tasty.

85/100

The taste is just as sweet as the smell. There is almost a dessert quality to the taste, with notes of chocolate, berries, honeycomb and a touch of salt. There is a taste hidden in there that reminds me of a sweet oatmeal. The finish has a delicate tingle of pepper with a subtle undertone of bitters and rubber.

Nose: honey or honeysuckle, almost brown sugar-like, lightest hint of vanilla, hint of savory nuttiness, then dominates with dried fruits. Together it almost reminds me of amaretto for a moment but very quick. Has that moment of that citrus touch from the original 10 year. Front-forward sherry tone, pleasant spice notes. Subsequent sips are never quite as satisfying as the first sip.  The peat becomes less noticeable and it becomes a game of replacing the aftertaste with a fresh sip. Malty spicy with finish of vanilla

Color is gold, but it’s likely artificial. Medium to high viscosity, clear, likely chill-filtered. Nose is moderate to low intensity, with black pepper, vanilla, and some caramel. Palate is rich and sweet, with raisins, sherry, vanilla, and oak. Finish is medium but sweet and fruity. You can definitely tell the sherry cask influence. Some water in this 43% ABV dram somewhat dulls it. It tames it quite a bit and presents less of everything. Finish shortens quite a bit as well. I wouldn’t add water to this one next time. Overall, this is a rich and sweet dram for sherry lovers. It’s not too complex, but it presents well and is quite enjoyable. Was a part of the 3 bottle package at Costco for $99. Well worth the price.

Flavor:  Sweet wine notes play with more dried dates and cherries.  Citrus peel abound.  

Finish:  Quite a bit of sweet barrel char, light cloves and tobacco almost like a clove cigarette, finishes sweeter than the other varieties.

I had not had the pleasure of sampling this malt mainly due to the fact that candidly it's not ever been one I have heard great things about. So I am hitting the local supermarket as the wife and kids want ice cream and I see this for $45! In my market it typically sells for close to $60 so I decided to grab it. Let's see if it's any good:
On the palette it's pretty rich with a decent mouthfeel. Rich caramel and honey notes give way to natural vanilla and plums. Some oak spice kicks in and then a decent red fruit driven finish. Quite a nice dram. Definitely on the sweeter side but well executed. Honestly outside of the Glendro 12 I don't know too many entry level Sherried malts I'd recommend over this. Not too complex but very drinkable for a great price! 

Cheers all!

Classic sherry finished scotch. With a cigar, this is beautiful.

With my review of the Lasanta, I've now reviewed entire lineup of the original Glenmorangie 12 year bottlings. Interestingly, this is the only of the three that has remained untouched after the revamp. This one is in the old packaging (the maroon one).

Nose: Sherry is immediately prominent. Red berry, date, fig, raisin, and plum.  Also some more generic Highland notes such as caramel, toffee, honey, and apple. Sweet and floral. Some cereal and perfume. Over time, a jam note appears. Rich in flavor but very approachable. Sweet and very interesting.

Palate: Sherry-rich once again. Leather, white grape, date, fig, raisin, and plum. Vanilla, caramel, and toffee. A bit of clementine-esque citrus. Some apple and jam. A very slight milk chocolate note, but far less than I get on other well-aged sherry-influenced malts. Similar to the palate, it's easy-going but complex enough to hold my attention.

Finish: Much like with the Quinta Ruban, there is a bit of drop-off here. It makes more sense with this one, considering it's the lowest of the 3 12 year olds at 43% ABV. Plum and the other dry-red fruit notes persist from the palate. Then, for the first time, I get some cinnamon and oak kick. A bit of clove, nutmeg, and pepper as well. It's short-to-moderate in length. Doesn't really add much to the experience.

Overall: Great bang for buck here. This one ran me $53, and it's a damn good value at that price point. Nothing out of the ordinary, but at the same time, this one hits all the right notes. The nose, if anything, is worthy of significant praise. Glad to see it's being kept in tact as Glenmorangie transitions its portfolio to a new format.

And that's my stamp on the 12-year line from GlenMo. It had a good run, and once the scavengers pick the scraps from the shelves, it'll be all but gone. This is significant to me because the Glenmorangie core 4 were some of the first single malts I've ever tried.

My analysis? These three Scotches did exactly what they were supposed to. Three role players. Glenmorangie took zero risks with these expressions, but also took no shortcuts. The result were rich, balanced whiskies that could be enjoyed by the masses and dissected by the experts.

And at the very least, I'm glad this one made the cut for the new generation of the GlenMo standard lineup.
Nicely sweet and a little spice keeps it interesting. A solid easy drinking scotch at this price

This is a very good sherry finished Scotch. It is not my favorite---I don't think the floral-fruity profile of Glenmorangie works as well with a sherry finish as the malted-honey of GlenDronach or Glenfarclas. Nevertheless, this is a fantastic malt. The expected floral and fruity notes of the Glenmo 10 are obviously there, and accented with a lovely sherry finish. This is not my favorite, but it is very good, can be found easily, and, if you shop carefully, it is somewhat affordable

P(2): way better the 4th sip. Forced it for the review. Initial tasted like it smelled. Final taste, light honey sweetness, medicinal, mint
F(2.5): long light finish. No burn no hug. vanilla after 3rd sip. Medicinal all the way. Dark chocolate. at 80% cacao

Actual score 1.83 out 5.

Second taste edit: Smoke hits me right away, which I didn’t taste before. It’s not as smooth as I remember either. Not bad by any means, still way better than the majority of drinkers say, but I have to bump it down to 4.0. It’s more nuanced and interesting than the Bacalta that I’m drinking at the same time, but it doesn’t hold up to the Quinta. 
Wow, this is surprisingly up there with the Quinta for me. Where the Quinta Ruban is bolder, with darker fruits taking center stage (blackberry, black currant, plum), this scotch is full of a little bit lighter fruits (raspberry, blueberry, strawberry). It’s as smooth, if not smoother than the Quinta. It has a slight bitterness that I've found to be characteristic of sherried scotches that detracts from the experience slightly. After hearing bad to average reviews, I didn’t expect much. It’s much better than advertised.

Some cobwebs and barnyard notes.
Smooth, soft, rich mouthfeel.  Very well balanced.  Rolled rye/oats mid palate and a chocolate finish.  
I'm not as fond of Sherry casked Scotch as I once was, but this is enjoyable. Some lingering warmth in the chest.

Light copper color. Heavy sherry notes on the nose, fruit-forward with lots of raisins, apricots and marachino cherries, hints of vanilla and marzipan. Light, dry mouthfeel. The palate is dominated by the sherry notes, with more stone fruits, light honey and spicy oak on the back palate. The finish is a continuation of the palate and is over pretty quickly. Good rich flavor to it. Raisin richness with a hint of sweetness. Full bodied with good flavor. Not the best, but not bad for the price.
Oh my, this is good. Spice, thicker mouthfeel, slight smokiness...excellent.
Sightly Smokey finish. Not my favorite.
Smokey finish. More complex than the 10 year classic. Not necessarily my favorite flavors- but you can still appreciate the spice.
Not too sweet, very enjoyable. If you like a sherry finish this is a bottle to try.
Bold and very sweet, but not as refined as the Nectar D'Or.

Nose: 6, 1-10 spicy, malt, hints of chocolate or cocoa.  Interesting enough to get a 6.

Color: rose gold

Taste: 7, 1-10 medium modied, you pick up on different notes each sip but lacks that final punch to round it off.  It builds in flavor from the front of the palate to the finish.  Signature Speyside tastes, with some peppery or spicey additions.  Not a lot, but enough to let you know it's been seasoned.  Overall an enjoyable Scotch that I enjoy at this price point.

Finish: 6, 1-10

Overall Score: 6 or 7, depends on the day on a 1-10.  I enjoy this scotch.  It's a scotch currently in my bar.  Good one to share, and also enjoy slowly solo after a long day, or just cause :). I am excited to try other Glenmorangie drams.

Palate- chocolate, raisins, malt forward

Finish- short finish bitter notes

Not a fan. Whatsoever. 10/10 would not recommend. Only bright spot is the flavor of raisins on the palate. Other than that, it’s one dimensional and has a weird bitter note on the finish.
Delicious sherry flavor. Low abv makes for a super easy drink.

Nose: sweet, sherry, plastic, apples, and sugar.

Taste: layers of flavor that comes right back to the nose at the end, I love that it returns to the beginning, I’ve never had that experience before.  Clean at first, then sweet citrus, orange zest, spice, and then honey.

Finish: stays for what seems like ages, don’t even want to take another sip yet.  Super long.  Cider, apples, vanilla, and smooth. 

A scotch that feels like it’s meant for a celebration, not everyday.  It’s like scotch wine.

Price is much cheaper than what I would expect it to be.  40 per 750ml and absolutely worth more.
Smooth and sweet with some ice and water,  otherwise harsh
I loved this one all day long!!!
Less sickeningly sweet than the Quinta ruban. I like it more. I do pick up on the ice cream and baking spices notes. It’s very warm and hearty. I’d buy it to share.

Pours dark amber. Nose is sherry foward. Sherry influence is present in the taste but there's a vanilla and chocolate presence from the bourbon barrels. Medium mouthfeel and finish. I generally prefer more robust flavors but this is on point. Very smooth.
Spicy, smokey, peppery, fruity... a lot going on here

Neat from a tester bottle that came with the regular Glenmorangie. The sherry/red wine component comes through early, with a plum/date sweetness. The second wave is characteristic orange peel, lemon grass, and potpourri spices. Flower petals. The smoke/peat is low. A very solid addition to the stable.
Really good. Most expensive purchase for whisky yet.
Very good bold flavor. Has a little bit of a peat taste but is sweet and smoky as well

I’m not much into Scotch but tasting this one has pushed me to explore more beyond the world of bourbon. The smokiness was not overwhelming and balanced well with the spice and fruitiness. I will be researching more scotch for sure. Thanks for the introduction @kirkgnomics

Nose: sweet sugar covered apples, Sherry, vanilla and cocoa
Palate: oily, raisins, milk chocolate, baking spice, red apples, bitter wood spice
Finish: medium to short, spicy raisins remains

Overall a great sipper, wish it was NCF and higher abv like its brother the QR but still good stands up to the macallan imo but much cheaper. At $40 its a good buy
Rich flavor, fruity. Would buy again
Big raisin nose, bit of peat. Don’t get much on the palate bit of tobacco on the finish.

Nose: sherry, sweet
Mouth: sweet, vanilla
Finish: short with spice
Really enjoy this. Warm, sweet, the sherry really comes through. Almost floral.

노즈: 쉐리 건포도향, 오렌지 껍질, 바닐라향
팔레트: 부드러움, 쉐리 스파이스, 달콤, 프루티함, 우디함
피니쉬: 계피맛, 우디함, 나무의 떫음, 피니쉬 짧음,
Notes of berry and vanilla. Very light smoke and cinnamon on the front end with a sweet dried fruit finish. Easy sipping.
Very smooth and flavorful... not a lot of complexity or depth... but nice.

A sherry-forward scotch, with a light body.  Following sips tell more of a bourbon cask life than a sherry maturation.  The finish is not spicy at all.  To pick out the bourbon maturation separately from the sherry finish is a first for me.  Pretty good, but simple for a single malt.



My Rating Glossary:  

Two Stars:           "I'd rather be drinking lite beer."
Two 1/2 Stars:    "Posh rubbish."
Three Stars:        "I love whisk(e)y.  This is average love."
Three 1/2 Stars: "May buy again."
Four Stars:          "I've got to get you into my life."
Four 1/2 Stars:   "Better than drugs."
Five Stars:           "Life is good.  Whisky makes it better."

#라산타 - 장미꽃
향 : 버번쉐리향
맛 : 달큼, 버번쉐리, 달콤
피니쉬 : 은은하고 약한 스파이시, 뒷꿀맛
Super sherry cask. Lovely tingly finish. Nutty at the middle note but very light at the end. Overall a fine dram (better than the necta d’or in my opinion). +has a barley-like taste
A lovely, sweet and thick nose. You can definitely pick up on the sherry cask. The finish seems a little shorter that I’d like, but I’d never turn it down. Would consider a second bottle.

Nose: First time I have gotten this smell, tobacco, burnt toast , oak, dry hay, tapioca.

Taste: grapes, toasted rice, apricot,
One of my favorite drams. Great taste for great value. Very creamy and sweet like maple syrup.

I know, I know, I really shouldn't like this bottle so much.  Heavy on the sherry, the color is unnaturally red, and it is the only bottle I have that doesn't show up in my Whiskeys of the World book as a recommended selection.  Buuuut... I love it.  In a taste test my son and I liked it as much if not more than Lagavulin 16, although granted they are nothing alike.  My good friend in AZ is also a fan.  And, to beat the band, I can find it all day long for $39.98 at my local whisky dealer.

Not what i expected it to be. Too normal and straightforward.

Bottled at 46%abv with an amber color.

On the nose: caramel, blackberry marmalade, liquorice, and a light peat.

On the palate: it is a spice bomb, very pleasant, it is a hot bomb too, some sugary note as toasted caramel, finish is oaky and with orange notes. Pleasant taste, but it lacks emotion.

Overall it is a 74 over 100. There are better single malts out there.
Just didn't do it for my palate. Way too much heavy sweetness and dried fruit. But would probably be good for those who like that.
Complex and great mouth feel. Even with a little ice the flavor holds up.

The aroma of the Sherry Cask finish leaps out of the glass. Hints of red grapes, raspberries, graham cracker and a heavy note of honey. The sweetness rolls through on the palate with a burnt sugar on the front end followed by a bitter dark chocolate and a black pepper finish

Scotch forward. Dark fruit like prune and raisin. Sweet and heavy. Smoke and spice. 

Dark and warm. Interesting in its own way, but overpriced for what it is. Not my jam, not a keeper for me.
A little bit of burn and some spicy notes. Sherry pops up right at the end.

Nose:
Vanilla sweet, creamy, few notes of toasted coconut, wood (oak)

Taste:
Kinda sweet, round, hints of green apple

Finish:
Long with a little bitterness, pleasant

Very nice bootle for the price.
My favorite!  Rich color and bold flavors. Broader in the mouth than most Speysides, the sherry cask finish elevates this with goodness.

On a taste it's a little prickly from spirits, sweet, honey and toffee, dried fruits as usual for sherry casks after these tastes appear some bitter notes. Aftertaste very short and isn't interesting. In the end I don't understand why does this whisky cost more then 50$ for 0,7 l bottle there're nothing interesting for this price.
A little light, very smooth, some sweetness and an easy finish.
Very interesting, intense and concentrated. Spicy and cinnamon..finish tastes like gingerbread cookies.
Smooth all the way through, cinnamon, barrel, dark fruits

Berries, fruits, spicy 2
Lingering spice 2
Vanilla, cinnamon, pepper, grass, apricot, oak.
It tastes and smells like a gingerbread cookie that's accompanied with an almond and hazelnut coffee with a sprinkle of amaretto around the corner waiting. Very tasty and highly recommended!
Tasting notes for me first is peaty, smokey, giving me a dry tongue and maybe the raisin ice cream they mention in the reviews.  Very oily leaving a dry tongue for sure.
